lines.text: [Squadron Leader Skipper and Simon are doing training in Spitfires. Skipper has just ordered Simon to engage him in a dogfight, but Simon has lost sight of him and is blinded by the sun. Suddenly Skipper bursts towards him from the sun]

[imitating a machine gun]
DAKA-DAKA-DAKA-DAKA-DAKA-DAKA-DAKA-DAKA-DAKA!
[flies past Simon]
Hello Rabbit Leader - thought you might come in from the sun!
DON'T THINK! Don't just glance! LOOK! Search for the bastards! OK, let's try it again.
David, we are not asking for anything. Europe is ours, we can walk into Britain whenever we like.

If you think we're going to gamble on Herr Hitler's guarantees, you're making a grave mistake. All those years in England seems to have left you none the wiser. We're not easily frightened. Also we know how hard it is for an army to cross the Channel. The last little Corporal who tried came a cropper. So don't threaten or dictate to us until you're marching up Whitehall... and even then we won't listen.
Churchill puts great faith in radar.
It's vital, but it won't shot down aircraft.
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: Ha... well I must say you don't, exactly exude a spirit of optimism.
God willing we will hold out minister.
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: I see. So I tell the cabinet, that you're trusting in radar and praying to God, is that right?

[chuckles]
more accurately the other way round. Trusting in god and praying for radar. But the essential arithmetic is that our young men will have to shoot down their young men at the rate of four to one, if we're to keep pace at all.
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: Put that cigarette out! The mains have gone, can't you smell gas?
Don't you yell at me, MR Warrick!

[ACM Dowding is sitting at his desk reading reports. The phone buzzes. AVM Evill picks up the phone]
Yes?
[listens]
Yes, one moment
[turns to ACM Dowding]
The Air Minister, sir. on the scrambler.

[picks up green scrambler phone]
Yes?
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: Ah, Dowding. Er. Look. Our people in Washington are having trouble with the American Press. It's about today's figures. German sources there are saying that our claims are wildly exaggerated.
[listens, but says nothing]
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: Hello? Are you there Dowding?
I'm here Minister.
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: Well I mean, can you verify the figures?

[clears throat]
I'm not very interested in propaganda. If we're right, they'll give up. If we are wrong, they'll be in London in a week!.
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: [pauses then hangs up]
[With the aid of an interpreter, Edwards has berated the Polish pilots for attacking German bombers against orders, before pulling a telegram out of his pocket]
[looks down]
"Congratulations! As of today, this Squadron is operational." Signed, Air Vice Marshall Keith Park, AOC 11 Group
[the men start cheering, and Squadron Leader Edwards smirks, before the scene changes to Dowding's office]
I was wrong about the Poles.
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: We also have the second Polish Squadron.

[Donning his cap]
I *thought* you'd mention them. Allright, make them operational.
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: And the Canadians?
And the Czechs. We need them *all!*
lines.character: Air Chief Marshall Sir Hugh Dowding

lines.text: [They exit]

[the British Spitfire pilots are having an easy time shooting down the feared German Stuka Dive Bombers]
It's like shooting rats in a barrel.
*You'll* be "in a barrel", if you don't watch out for the *fighters*!
The *engine's* overheating, and so am *I*! Either we stand down, or *blow up*! Now *which* do you want?
[Narration]
Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few.
[to his flight of non-English-speaking Polish pilots]
Shut up! Silence - in Polish!

[His squadron has just been scrambled and is also under attack by the Luftwaffe]
Well don't just *stand* there! Get one *up!*
I left out the bit about the wolf whistles. You're better at it then I am.
The Erks have other things on their minds these days thank goodness!
[Park has just landed, to be met by Group Captain Hope]
Bad as we thought, Sir?

[upset]
Worse! Kenley and Biggin are a *shambles* and the rest not much better. God Knows how many aircraft we'll have in the morning! All because 12 Group couldn't do their stuff. Leigh-Mallory and his big wings! Might as well stay on the *ground* for all the *use* they are!
Where have you been?

[soaking wet and miffed]
Learning to swim!
Did you get one?
All I got was a bellyful of English Channel!
How many time have I told you - never fly straight and level for more than 30 seconds in a combat area!
[pauses]
You call your wife?
[Andy shakes his head slightly]
All right, boy! Get in!
[cocks his head toward his small maroon Austin Ascot 12/6]
[Sgt Pilot Andy is reading a letter, while the pilots are waiting for the call to scramble]
Silly Bitch!
He's calling you names again, Arnold!
I spend half my leave getting her settled in the country, and now, "I'm bored", she says!
[British pilots in France are listening to a French officer talking about the German advance]
For the benefit of the uneducated among us, I shall now translate.
[the Germans are about to overrun the airfield]
Right! Let's get the hell out of here!
Where are we going, sir?

[Walking rapidly toward his plane]
Why don't you follow me and find out?
[after berating Simon, a young pilot]
How many hours in Spits?
Ten and a half, sir.
Let's make it *eleven*, before *Jerry* has you for *breakfast!*
Spring chicken to shitehawk in one easy lesson.
[at low volume, almost whispering, after Simon and Skipper leave the building for their aircraft]
daka!-daka!-daka!-daka!-daka!-daka!-daka!-daka!
Corporal! Re-fuel them immediately.
Yes, sir.
[Turns back to the other ground crew]
So anyway...
[continues his conversation]
Corporal - I don't mean with your blood! And re-arm them!
Yes, *sir*!
[Runs towards the aircraft]
stay single.

[Polish pilot parachutes from his plane when it is shot down. He lands in a hayfield]
Good afternoon,sir
[in a Polish accent]

[the farmer points a pitch fork at the pilot thinking he's German, and replies in an angry sarcastic voice]
Good afternoon my arse, you boche bastard. Come on put your hands up.
Why?
Come on, put 'em up.
I'm a Polish pilot, I'm fighting on your side.

[hanging up the phone and looking down at the plotting table, showing a large number of RAF Squadrons in place to intercept a Luftwaffe raid on London]
This should give them something to think about!

[during the raids on September 15th]
Is everything up?
The lot, Sir!
Reserves?
None!
That's what I've just told the Prime Minister!
[walks back into office with Winston Churchill watching the progress]

[on being told that the radar stations are out of action due to German bombing]
So we're blind, so now we've only got the Observer Corps!
Section Officer Harvey!
[yells]
Sir
[walks up to him and gives a salute, which he returns]
Section Officer Harvey, I've noticed that some of your girls are now using the men's trenches during air raid practice. It's got to stop.
Sir
And another thing... Gas mask cases
[tapping Maggie's case]
They're for gas masks, They're not handbags. I do realize, of course, that female requirement differ somewhat from the male. Nevertheless that's no excuse...
[stops in mid sentence as he hears German bombs exploding behind him. He and Harvey turn around and see bombers approaching]
God's teeth!
[at full volume]
Take cover!
[Baker and Harvey run into the same nearby trench]

[protesting to Dowding]
We were up, sir, trying to knock out the enemy air mass. It takes time to assemble forty or fifty aircraft at...

[interrupting]
It takes far too long! By the time your "Big Wing" is up, the enemies have already hit their targets and are on their way home.
All that matters is to shoot them down in large numbers. I'd rather destroy fifty after they've hit their targets than ten before.
Don't forget, the targets are my airfields, Leigh-Mallory. And you're not getting fifty. You're not even getting ten!
Never let me catch you doing a victory roll over my airfield again. Understood?

[after watching a Hurricane perform a victory roll]
Who's he trying to kid!

[Novice pilot Simon has made a very bad landing]
You can teach...

[joins in]
... *monkeys* to fly better than that!

[to Squadron Leader Colin Henry]
I'm just not cut out to wave a wet hanky and sooty stations.
